fields.headline: My media
fields.bodyText: Newspapers: I like to skim through a cross-section of the broadsheets and tabloids and pick out the bits. But my papers of choice are the Guardian, the Independent, the Observer and the Sunday Times. When I'm in the US, I try to get the New York Times and the New York Post. Magazines: I rarely buy them. We're decorating, so Elle Decoration has been all the rage. We've bought the London Evening Standard religiously for the style section. But it's years since I've bought a women's magazine. Books: A month ago, when I put my back out and had to spend several days in bed, I read Jack and Jackie: Portrait of an American Marriage by Christopher Andersen. It didn't tell me much that I didn't know, but it was a great read. TV: Working in the business, I try to watch as many news programmes as possible: all the traditional ones, BBC News at six o'clock, the ITV News, Channel 4 News, of course, and CNN and all the other rolling news networks. I also watch the US programmes - NBC News and CBS News. We cover more international news. Generally, I think there's little to watch. I have cable, with 40 channels, but I'm constantly surfing for something decent. I'm a fan of Frasier, Graham Norton and the Antiques Road Show and a recent convert to The West Wing. Radio: Radio 5 Live's Up All Night - it's a great mix of news, stories and interviews. Adverts: I tend to flip over or make a cup of tea when they come on. But I like the Sainsbury's ones with the Naked Chef, and the Barclays one, with the actor from Pulp Fiction. New media: I'm a huge, huge internet fan. I don't know how I managed without it. I'm working on a series of documentaries for PBS, and I've been using the internet for research - Nexus Lexus, the Economist online and the Guardian website. · Former Channel 4 News and ITN world news presenter Daljit Dhaliwal is now joining CNN International.
